wiki.text:
{{Taxobox
| image = Koeh-113.jpg
|regnum = Plantae |unranked_divisio = Angiosperms |unranked_classis = Eudicots
|unranked_ordo = Rosids
| ordo = Rosales familia = Rosaceae genus = [[Prunus]] subgenus = [[Prunus
| subgenus Cerasus|Cerasus]] species = 'P. cerasus' binomial = Prunus cerasus
| binomial_authority = L.
}}

'Prunus cerasus' ('sour [[cherry]]', 'tart cherry' or 'wild cherry') is a
species of [[Prunus]] in the subgenus [[Cherry|Cerasus]] (cherries), native to
much of Europe and southwest Asia. It is closely related to the sweet cherry
([[Prunus avium]]), but has a fruit that is more acidic.

The tree is smaller than the sweet cherry (growing to a height of 4–10 m),
has twiggy branches, and its crimson-to-near-black cherries are borne upon
shorter stalks.

There are two varieties of the 'sour cherry': the dark-red 'morello cherry' and
the lighter-red 'amarelle cherry'.<ref>Webster’s New International Dictionary of
the English Language. Springfield, Massachusetts: G. & C. Merriam Co., 1913. See
amarelle at p. 67.</ref>
wiki.title: prunus cerasus
